Title: Effects of pile cap thickness and magnitudes of lateral movement on laterally loaded group piles
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Gouw, T.-L., Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Irpan, H., Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Abstract: The capacity of laterally loaded group piles are conventionally analyzed by simply reducing the lateral subgrade reaction of the soil, kh. The lateral subgrade reaction is reduced to 0.35 kh, when the piles center to center distance is at 3 pile diameter and linearly increases up to 1.0 kh when the piles center to center distance is equal or higher than 8 pile diameter. It seems there is no consideration to the thickness of the pile cap and magnitude of lateral movement of the piles on this conventional approach. By using 3D finite element geotechnical software, the effect of these two factors can now be investigated. This paper presents the study on the impact of those two factors on lateral capacity of group piles. The study reveals that when base friction of the pile cap and the passive pressure acting against the pile cap is neglected, the effects of the pile cap thickness against group lateral efficiency is marginal and can be safely neglected. The center to center pile spacing and the lateral movement of the piles do play important roles in the capacity of the laterally loaded piles. The greater the pile spacing the greater the lateral group efficiency, so does the lateral movement. © 2015 ejge.
Author Keywords: Finite element 3D analysis; Pile cap thickness; Pile lateral capacity
Index Keywords: Efficiency; Finite element method; Pile driving; Soil structure interactions; 3-D finite elements; 3-D-analysis; Conventional approach; Laterally loaded pile; Passive pressure; Pile caps; Pile lateral capacities; Subgrade reactions; Piles; finite element method; loading; magnitude; movement; pile group
